abstract.p: Letter from Dr Richard P Wenzel, chairman of Department of Internal Medicine at Virginia Commonwealth University, opposes Clinton administration plan to fine medical investigators who violate federal human research rules

block.p: Re ''Fines Proposed for Violations of Human Research Rules'' (news article, May 24): The Clinton administration's proposal to levy fines on medical investigators found to violate federal human research rules is shortsighted and simplistic. There is no evidence that increased paperwork, training in bioethics or financial threats make a person more ethical or more responsible.

Re ''Fines Proposed for Violations of Human Research Rules'' (news article, May 24): The Clinton administration's proposal to levy fines on medical investigators found to violate federal human research rules is shortsighted and simplistic. There is no evidence that increased paperwork, training in bioethics or financial threats make a person more ethical or more responsible.

The best pressures are not bureaucratic or financial. They are social. An institution needs to create a culture that will not tolerate poor ethical and professional standards. Second, from a risk management perspective, redundant systems need to be in place to minimize the chance of error or poor judgment. Finally, internal audits followed by external surveys, like those routinely used in hospitals and graduate medical education, might help.
RICHARD P. WENZEL, M.D. Chairman, Dept. of Internal Medicine Virginia Commonwealth University Richmond, Va., May 24, 2000
